mainTopic.title: Oral Cavity and Salivary Glands
mainTopic.content_info: While the lectures are good for getting an idea of the structure of the course, the slides mostly contain images and diagrams, so to get more detailed information it is best to look through the lecture handouts, which follow the structure of the lecture only with more detailed descripitions, and the student notes which are not only more detailed but cover more topics than the lectures.

quizzes.question: Which part of the oral cavity has lining mucosa, masticatory mucosa and specialized mucosa and what are the characteristics of their epithelium and submucosa?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Lining mucosa:  lip, cheek, floor of mouth, soft palate, ventral surface of tongue has non-keratinized epithelium and salivary glands can be found in the submucosa; Masticatory mucosa: gingiva and hard palate has keratinized or parakeratinized epithelium with an absent submucosa; Specialized mucosa: dorsal surface of the tounge
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Lining mucosa covers the dorsal surface of the tongue, masticatory mucosa is found on the soft palate, and specialized mucosa is only present on the ventral surface of the tongue
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Masticatory mucosa has non-keratinized epithelium, while lining mucosa is always keratinized and does not contain salivary glands in the submucosa
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Specialized mucosa is found in the gingiva, and lining mucosa is found on the dorsal tongue surface with a keratinized epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The entire oral cavity is covered by keratinized epithelium, and submucosa is present in all types of mucosa

quizzes.question: What characterises the mucosa of the different papillae?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Filiform papillae:  keratinized epithelium; Fungiform papillae: non-keratinized epithelium; Circumvallate papillae: non-keratinized epithelium with associated taste buds and von Ebner’s salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Filiform papillae have non-keratinized epithelium, while fungiform papillae are keratinized
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Circumvallate papillae lack taste buds and have keratinized epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Fungiform papillae are associated with von Ebner’s glands and contain keratinized epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: All papillae are keratinized and contain taste buds

quizzes.question: What characterises the tissue covering the three sides of the lip?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Oral mucosa: nonkeratinized epithelium, labial salivary glands in submucosa; Vermillion border (zone): Dilated venules and veins, submucosa lacks salivary glands; Skin: hair follicles, sebaceous glands, sweat glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Oral mucosa contains keratinized epithelium, and the vermillion border has salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Gingival mucosa contains parakeratinized epithelium, and the vermillion border has salivary glands with no bloodvessels in the submucosa
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The skin side of the lip has non-keratinized epithelium with no glands, while the oral mucosa contains sebaceous glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The vermillion border has a thick layer of keratinized epithelium and contains minor salivary glands

quizzes.question: What are the specialized structures found on the dorsal surface of the tongue and which ones contain tastebuds?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Papilli: the ones that contain tastebuds: fungiform, foliate, and circumvallate papillae​, and the filiform papillae doesn't contain tastebuds
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Filiform papillae contain taste buds, while fungiform papillae do not
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Circumvallate papillae are absent in humans, and only filiform and foliate papillae contain taste buds
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Fungiform papillae are responsible for mechanical processing, and taste buds are only found on the ventral tongue
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: All papillae on the tongue contain taste buds, including filiform papillae

quizzes.question: Which papillae are rudimentary in humans?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Foliate papillae​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Filiform papillae
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Fungiform papillae
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Circumvallate papillae
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: All papillae are well-developed in humans

quizzes.question: What is the role of keratinization in the oral mucosa?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Keratinization provides mechanical protection in areas subject to friction, such as the gingiva and hard palate​. Non-keratinized epithelium is found in the lining mucosa and is more flexible, while keratinized epithelium is in masticatory mucosa and provides greater protection​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Keratinization occurs only in lining mucosa and helps with saliva production
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Keratinization makes all mucosa waterproof, preventing water loss in the oral cavity
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: All areas of the oral cavity are keratinized, providing uniform protection
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Keratinization is absent in masticatory mucosa and is only found in the specialized mucosa

quizzes.question: Why is the submucosa absent in masticatory mucosa?
quizzes.goodAnswer: The mucosa is tightly bound to the underlying bone, which provides firm support​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The submucosa is present in all types of mucosa, including masticatory mucosa
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Masticatory mucosa lacks a submucosa because it is loosely attached to muscles
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The submucosa is absent in all mucosal types, not just masticatory mucosa
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Masticatory mucosa does not require a submucosa because it produces saliva amd doesn't provide any mechanical stability

quizzes.question: What is the primary function of the mucosa in the oral cavity?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Protection, sensation, and secretion​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The primary function is digestion and absorption
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The mucosa is primarily responsible for immune response
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Its main role is to store nutrients and water
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It plays no functional role other than structural support

quizzes.question: What is the function of von Ebner’s glands?
quizzes.goodAnswer: They secrete serous fluid that helps wash away food particles from taste buds​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: They produce mucus for lubrication
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: They are responsible for producing amylase to aid digestion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: They do not contribute to saliva secretion but help in immune defense
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: They are present in the lining mucosa and aid in keratinization

quizzes.question: What components make up a tooth?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Dentin, enamel, cementum
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Pulp, keratin, adipose tissues
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Bone, tendon, cartilage
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cementum, epidermis, marrow
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Dentin, bone, tendon

quizzes.question: What is the hardest substance in the human body and what is it's main mineral component?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Enamel, and Hydroxyapatite (calcium phosphate)​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Dentin, and Calcium carbonate
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Bone, and Hydroxyapatite (magnesium phosphate)
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cementum, and Fluorapatite
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Enamel, and Collagen fibers

quizzes.question: Which cells are responsible for the formation of enamel and which are responsible for dentin production?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Enamel: ameloblasts, Dentin: odontoblasts
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Enamel: Odontoblasts, Dentin: Cementocytes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Enamel: Cementoblasts, Dentin: Ameloblasts
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Enamel: Fibroblasts, Dentin: Osteoblasts
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Enamel: Chondrocytes, Dentin: Osteoclasts

quizzes.question: What is dentin composed of?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It is primarily composed of hydroxyapatite and collagen
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: It is composed of fluoride and calcium carbonate
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It is primarily made of keratin and elastic fibers
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: It contains only hydroxyapatite, without organic components
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It is mainly composed of glycoproteins and calcium sulfate

quizzes.question: How does tooth erosion occur and what are the consequences of enamel loss?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It occurs due to acid exposure and mechanical wear​. Increased tooth sensitivity and risk of decay​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Tooth erosion occurs due to excess saliva production, leading to harder enamel
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Enamel loss results in stronger teeth and improved resistance to decay
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Mechanical wear alone does not cause erosion, as enamel regenerates over time
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Enamel loss only affects the color of the teeth and does not contribute to sensitivity or decay

quizzes.question: What is the difference between cellular and acellular cementum?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Cellular cementum contains living cells (cementocytes), while acellular cementum does not​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Both cellular and acellular cementum contain cementocytes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Acellular cementum has living cells, while cellular cementum does not
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cellular cementum is found only in the crown, while acellular cementum is found in the root
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Not every tooth has cementum, while every tooth has acellular cementum

quizzes.question: What are the three major salivary glands?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Parotid, Submandibular and Sublingual salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Lingual, Buccal and Oral salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Submandibular, Buccal and Sublingual salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Palatine, Parotid and Oral salivary glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Sublingual, Lingual and Temporal salivary glands

quizzes.question: What parts does the functional and the structural unit of the salivary gland have?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Acinus, Intercalated duct, Striated duct
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Lobule, capillary loop, excretory vacuole
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Epithelium, basement membrane, goblet cell
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cortex, trabeculae, lymphatic sinus
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Follicle, medullary duct, secretory vesicle

quizzes.question: What are the main components of acinar cells and what type of epithelium lines the salivary ducts?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Serous or mucous-producing cells​ make up the acinus and the ducts are lined by cuboidal to columnar epithelium​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Acinar cells are made up of only keratinocytes, and salivary ducts are lined with stratified squamous epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Only mucous cells are found in acini, and ducts are lined with simple squamous epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Serous acini produce thick mucus, and ducts are lined with pseudostratified epithelium
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Myoepithelial cells form the acinus, and ducts are lined with transitional epithelium

quizzes.question: What is the role of intercalated and striated ducts in salivary glands?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Intercalated ducts mainly transport saliva from acini and modify its composition​, while striated ducts reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium and bicarbonate​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Intercalated ducts are responsible for secreting enzymes, while striated ducts store saliva
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Striated ducts only transport saliva and do not modify its composition
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Intercalated ducts reabsorb sodium, while striated ducts transport saliva to the bloodstream
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Both intercalated and striated ducts store saliva before secretion

quizzes.question: Which contractile cell type surrounds the acini of salivary glands and helps expel saliva?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Myoepithelial cell
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Goblet cell
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Acinar cell
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Fibroblast
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Chondrocyte

quizzes.question: How do mucous and serous acini differ in function?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Serous acini produce watery enzyme-rich fluid, while mucous acini produce thick mucus​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Mucous acini produce watery secretions, while serous acini produce thick mucus
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Both mucous and serous acini secrete only enzymes, not fluids
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Serous acini produce mucus, while mucous acini produce amylase-rich fluid
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Serous acini function only in the parotid gland, while mucous acini function only in the submandibular gland

quizzes.question: Which salivary gland is mostly serous?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Parotid gland
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Submandibular gland
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Sublingual gland
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Lindual gland
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Palatine gland

subTopics.title: Mechanism and Regulation of Saliva Secretion

quizzes.question: Which cranial nerves are involved in salivary gland innervation?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Cranial nerves V (trigeminal), VII (facial), and IX (glossopharyngeal)​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Cranial nerves III (oculomotor), V (trigeminal), and X (vagus).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Cranial nerves IV (trochlear), VII (facial), and XII (hypoglossal).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cranial nerves VI (abducens), VIII (vestibulocochlear), and X (vagus).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Only cranial nerve X (vagus) controls all salivary gland innervation.

quizzes.question: What happens to saliva as it moves through the duct system?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It becomes hypotonic due to sodium and chloride reabsorption while potassium and bicarbonate are secreted​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva becomes isotonic as it moves through the ducts
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Potassium and chloride are reabsorbed, while sodium and bicarbonate are secreted
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva remains unchanged as it passes through the ducts
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Water is reabsorbed, making saliva hypertonic

quizzes.question: What is the daily production volume of saliva and how does the flow rate of saliva affect its composition and what is the consequence of prolonged reduced saliva production?
quizzes.goodAnswer: About 1,000 mL (1 liter) per day​. At low flow rates, saliva is more hypotonic; at high flow rates, it becomes closer to plasma composition​. A prolonged reduction in saliva production means an increased risk of infections, dental cavities, and discomfort​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva production is 2-3 liters per day, and the composition remains constant at all flow rates
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: At low flow rates, saliva is hypertonic, and at high flow rates, it becomes more hypotonic
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva production does not affect oral health, as other fluids compensate for its absence
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: A prolonged reduction in saliva leads to an increase in bacterial growth but does not affect dental health

quizzes.question: What is the difference between minor and major salivary glands and which produces the most saliva at rest?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Major glands (parotid, submandibular, sublingual) produce most of the saliva, while minor glands contribute small amounts mainly for mucosal hydration​ and the submandibular gland​ produces the most saliva at rest
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Minor glands, while being smaller in size, produce more saliva than major glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The Major glands are mostly serous and the minor glands are mucous, the parotid gland produces the most saliva at rest
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The difference between major and minor salivary glands is their size, and the sublingual gland is the largest and produces the most saliva.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Major salivary glands do not contribute to mucosal hydration, only secrete enzymes, and the Sublingual gland produces the most saliva at rest

quizzes.question: How does the sympathetic and the parasympathetic nervous system influence saliva production?
quizzes.goodAnswer: The sympathetic response reduces the overall volume but increases protein content, making saliva thicker through beta-adrenergic receptors​,while the parasympathetic nervous system increases saliva flow through acetylcholine release, stimulating serous secretion​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The sympathetic system increases watery saliva production, while the parasympathetic system reduces saliva secretion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Both systems decrease saliva production under normal conditions
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Parasympathetic stimulation causes thick mucus secretion, and the sympathetic nervous system inhibits the synthesis of enzymes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The sympathetic system has no effect on saliva production, but the parasympathetic nervous system increases the rate of saliva production

quizzes.question: What are the primary functions of saliva in digestion?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Lubrication, starch digestion, and taste facilitation​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva functions only to moisten food with no digestive role
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Saliva mainly absorbs nutrients from food
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva helps in fat digestion but not starch digestion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Saliva neutralizes stomach acids but has no role in taste perception

quizzes.question: What is the role of kallikrein in blood flow to salivary glands?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It produces bradykinin, a vasodilator that increases blood flow during secretion​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: It constricts blood vessels to prevent excess saliva production
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It increases sodium levels in saliva but has no effect on blood flow
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: It produces epinephrine, which reduces blood supply to the glands
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It regulates only the minor salivary glands and does not affect major glands

quizzes.question: What is the primary function of the sublingual gland?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It mainly secretes mucus to lubricate the oral cavity​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: It produces only serous secretions
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It is responsible for the majority of enzyme secretion in the mouth
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: It produces the most saliva during rest
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It has no function in saliva production

quizzes.question: What is xerostomia, and what are its causes?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Xerostomia (dry mouth) is caused by medications (anicholinergic drugs), radiation therapy, or autoimmune diseases like Sjögren’s syndrome​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Xerostomia means excess digestion, and it is caused by excessive saliva production
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It is a genetic disorder with no known environmental causes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: It's an autoimmune disease that occurs only in elderly patients and has no known treatment
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It's diagnostic signs that is caused by high water intake and increased saliva production

quizzes.question: What factors stimulate saliva production?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Taste, smell, and chewing activate the salivatory nuclei​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Sleep, fear, and fatigue increase saliva production
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Saliva secretion is only controlled by hormones, not external stimuli
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Chewing decreases saliva production to prevent excessive fluid loss
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Hearing and vision are the primary factors in stimulating saliva secretion

quizzes.question: How does sleep affect saliva secretion?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Saliva production decreases significantly during sleep​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva production remains constant during sleep
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Sleep increases saliva flow to protect the mouth from bacteria
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Salivary glands shut down completely during sleep
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Saliva becomes hypertonic during sleep due to high water absorption

quizzes.question: What role does aldosterone play in saliva composition?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It decreases sodium and increases potassium concentration in saliva​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: It increases sodium and decreases potassium concentration
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It regulates only water content, not ion concentration
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: It prevents saliva secretion by acting on the nervous system
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It reduces bicarbonate levels to make saliva acidic

quizzes.question: What role do oral mechanoreceptors play in saliva secretion?
quizzes.goodAnswer: They detect chewing movements and stimulate saliva production via the nervous system​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: They detect taste and directly trigger salivary gland secretion without nervous system involvement
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Mechanoreceptors only respond to temperature changes, not chewing movements
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: They inhibit saliva production to prevent excessive fluid loss during eating
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: They are responsible for detecting pain but do not influence saliva secretion

quizzes.question: How does saliva assist in taste perception?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It dissolves food particles, allowing taste buds to detect flavors​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva prevents taste perception by coating the taste buds
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Taste buds detect flavors independently, and saliva plays no role in the process
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva only lubricates food and does not interact with taste receptors
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Saliva alters the chemical structure of food, making it tasteless

quizzes.question: How does dehydration affect saliva production?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It reduces saliva flow, leading to dry mouth​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Dehydration increases saliva production to compensate for fluid loss
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Saliva production remains constant regardless of hydration levels
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Dehydration makes saliva more watery to aid in swallowing
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Saliva flow increases during dehydration to maintain oral pH balance

quizzes.question: What are the main components of saliva?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Water, bicarbonate, potassium, sodium, chloride, glycoproteins (mucus), enzymes (amylase), and antibacterial compounds (lysozyme, lactoferrin, IgA)​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva contains only water and enzymes, with no minerals or antibacterial components
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The primary component of saliva is glucose, which provides energy for oral bacteria
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva consists of hydrochloric acid, which helps break down food in the mouth
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Saliva is primarily composed of fats and proteins rather than water and electrolytes

quizzes.question: What is the function of bicarbonate in saliva?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It neutralizes acids in food and stomach regurgitation​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Bicarbonate acidifies saliva to aid in digestion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It enhances the absorption of sugars in the mouth
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Bicarbonate functions solely as a lubricant and has no role in acid neutralization
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It is responsible for breaking down proteins in food

quizzes.question: What type of enzyme is salivary amylase what is its role in digestion?
quizzes.goodAnswer: A hydrolase enzyme that breaks down starch by cleaving α-1,4 glycosidic bonds​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Salivary amylase is a protease that digests proteins
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It is a lipase enzyme responsible for fat digestion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Salivary amylase breaks down cellulose instead of starch
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It functions as an acid that dissolves food particles

quizzes.question: How does saliva contribute to oral hygiene?
quizzes.goodAnswer: It contains antibacterial compounds like lysozyme, lactoferrin, and IgA, which prevent bacterial growth and bad breath​
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Saliva promotes bacterial growth to aid digestion
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It contains only water and has no antibacterial properties
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Saliva neutralizes bacteria by increasing glucose concentration
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Its primary function is taste perception, with no role in hygiene
